title: 111_hr2274
content: The Act is titled the "Priorities in Education Spending Act" and pertains to elementary and secondary education programs. The "Priorities in Education Spending Act" repeals various provisions of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 related to family literacy programs, school libraries, Close Up Fellowship program, comprehensive school reform, school leadership, advanced certification, National Writing Project, and teaching traditional American history. The Priorities in Education Spending Act repeals provisions related to various education programs, including technology enhancement, immigrant education, alcohol abuse reduction grants, mentoring programs, counseling programs, smaller learning communities, book distribution, and the Star Schools Act. The Priorities in Education Spending Act repeals provisions related to various education programs, including technology enhancement, immigrant education, alcohol abuse reduction grants, mentoring programs, counseling programs, smaller learning communities, book distribution, and several other specific programs under title V of the act. The Priorities in Education Spending Act repeals provisions related to various education programs under title V of the act, including grants for mental health improvement, arts in education, healthy schools, assistance for local educational agencies impacted by Federal property acquisition, Women's Educational Equity Act, Native Hawaiian Education Act, and Alaska Native Educational Equity Act. The Early Learning Opportunities Act under Title VIII of H.R. 5656 of the 106th Congress is repealed by section 1 of Public Law 106-554. Additionally, provisions related to various education programs under title V of the act are also repealed. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to repeal several provisions, including sections related to Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian-serving Institutions, Byrd Honors Scholarships, TEACH Grants, Default Reduction Management program, loan repayment for civil legal assistance attorneys, the Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program, demonstration projects to support postsecondary faculty, staff, and administrators in educating students with disabilities, and Part E of title VII. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to include various programs such as the College Access Challenge Grant program, business workforce partnerships for job training, the Patsy Mink Fellowship program, Early Childhood Education Professional Development, STEM education for Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian students, pilot programs for college success, and low tuition initiatives. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to include various programs such as low tuition, cooperative education, creating bridges from jobs to careers, grants to rural-serving institutions, training for realtime writers, Modeling and Simulation programs, the path to success, School of Veterinary Medicine Competitive Grant program, and the Henry Kuualoha Giugni Kupuna Memorial Archives. Additionally, provisions of the Higher Education Amendments of 1998 are repealed. The Higher Education Amendments of 1998 repeal various provisions related to programs for incarcerated youth, the Underground Railroad, cultural experiences grants, research in advanced technologies, minority-serving institutions, and Olympic scholarships. The text repeals various education programs for prisoners, loan repayment for prosecutors and public defenders, career and technical education programs, Special Olympics Sport and Empowerment Act of 2004 program, and Head Start Act program. The text repeals various education programs related to early childhood, workforce investment, environmental education, and provisions of the America COMPETES Act.
